race.name: Rasputitsa Spring Classic
race.tagline: Vermont spring mud season mountain gravel in Burke.

climate.description: Spring mud season with cold, wet, and variable conditions.

terrain.primary: Vermont mountainous gravel with spring mud
terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Vermont mountains with spring mud season conditions. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Vermont spring mud event. Unique conditions and mountain terrain but regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Rasputitsa Spring Classic is a Vermont spring gravel race—mountain terrain with spring mud season conditions. The unique spring mud challenge, significant climbing, and Vermont reputation elevate it above typical regional events, but the regional field keeps it in Tier 3. Burke provides moderate access. Well-organized for a spring mud event with 300-600 riders embracing the unique conditions.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A unique Vermont spring mud mountain gravel race. Worth it for the spring mud challenge and mountain terrain. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers, but a legitimate spring mud test.

final_verdict.one_liner: Vermont spring mud season mountain gravel in Burke.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you want a unique spring mud mountain challenge—yes, it's a legitimate test. If you want dry conditions or pro field depth—look elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Vermont events: Vermont Overland. For similar spring mud events: other spring gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Burke has limited lodging. Lyndonville or St. Johnsbury have more options.
logistics.food: Small area with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

history.origin_story: Vermont spring mud season gravel event.

course_description.character: Mountainous Vermont gravel with spring mud.
course_description.signature_challenge: Vermont mountain climbing in spring mud season conditions.

guide_variables.race_terrain: Vermont mountainous gravel with spring mud

non_negotiables.why: Spring mud season requires specific handling and equipment skills.
Vermont mountains require solid climbing fitness (5000 feet).
Vermont spring means cold and wet conditions.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Vermont spring mud season mountain gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Unique spring mud challenge in Burke.

logistics.explanation: Remote Burke/Jay location in Vermont's Northeast Kingdom limits accessibility, though race founder Heidi Myers notes the event has grown to 1500 people. Multiple distance options (20-100 miles) provide flexibility for travel planning. Local inns promote race packages, but the mountain location still requires commitment to reach.

length.explanation: Multiple distance options from 20 to 100 miles let riders adjust race morning—one competitive rider downgraded from 75 to 63 miles at registration. The $85 entry fee reflects standard gravel pricing. Route design allows bail-out options at aid stations for riders who overestimated their fitness. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The infamous Cyberia section earns its reputation as 'a scary backwoods where at any time a Yeti or Bengal tiger may jump out of the woods, bludgeon you with a blunt object.' Hills average 8.5% grade over nearly a mile, with one rider noting 'Many were already walking' on the first major climb at mile 13. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: After mile 13, 'there are almost no flat portions—you are either riding up a hill or down a hill.' Climbs hit 8.5% grades sustained over 0.8 miles each. One rider reported walking steep sections despite solid fitness, noting the relentless nature of Vermont's rolling terrain. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Spring conditions swing from cloudy 50°F mornings to sunny warmth that causes sunburn by afternoon. One rider noted 'Sweat up the hill, cool down on the descent' while switching from full-finger to fingerless gloves mid-race. The Russian name means 'mud season when roads become difficult to traverse.' Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Vermont's Northeast Kingdom keeps elevations well below any physiological impact. Burke Mountain area peaks stay under 3,000 feet, so your cardiovascular system won't notice altitude—just the 8.5% sustained climbs that define the terrain. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing through mud and potential snow while overlooking Canada in Vermont's remote mountains delivers adventure. Weather that's 'merciless on wheeled transport' means you'll earn stories worth telling. This homegrown event puts you at nature's mercy, not some sanitized gravel theme park. As Event Philosophy puts it: "Rasputitsa transcends the realm of a mere gravel cycling race; it embodies a homegrown, self-supported endeavor that tests the limits of the mind, body, and soul..."

prestige.explanation: Pro participation includes Ted King, Alison Tetrick, Tim Johnson, and Lyne Bessette, while Olympian Lea Davison personally helps with equipment recommendations. The race attracts 1500 riders annually and earns recognition in gravel circles, though it maintains grassroots character over corporate polish.

race_quality.explanation: Well-stocked aid stations provide pb&js, bananas, and tacos at mile 45, with pace sheets sent pre-race to help riders time cutoffs. The homegrown organization shows in practical details—mass start led by founder's truck through downtown, clear bailout instructions, and 'We won't leave anyone out there' messaging.

experience.explanation: Co-founder Heidi Myers calls it 'a homegrown self-supported challenge of the mind, body, and soul that instills people with a connected sense of place.' Race day brings 'a zillion hugs and handshakes' with railroad-grade gravel sections and grassy doubletrack creating varied terrain through Vermont's mountains.

community.explanation: Myers describes gravel organizers as 'beyond a community. We are family,' with her sons working as staff photographer and retail sales. The event supports the Mary E. Wright Halo Foundation while maintaining mass-start format that 'ends in a shared beer at the finish line regardless of your ability.'

field_depth.explanation: Elite riders start at 8am while recreational participants join the 9am mass start, creating natural separation. One competitive rider noted being 'one of Very Few not wearing a full road cycling kit,' suggesting the field skews toward weekend warriors over serious racers in remote Vermont. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Recent Editions puts it: "The last two editions have been raced on fast, dry roads and clear, warm days (as opposed to the snowbound slugfests of previous years)."

value.explanation: At $85 entry fee with multiple distance options and well-supported aid stations, the pricing reflects standard gravel economics. Pre-race communication includes logistics and pace sheets, with post-race food (pizza or pasta) included. The self-supported model keeps costs reasonable without corporate markup.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-120. Burke offers everything from B&Bs to campgrounds, giving you options beyond resort pricing. But this is remote northern Vermont—you're not finding budget motels everywhere. The Wildflower Inn promotes race packages, which means local businesses know how to extract tourist dollars from gravel pilgrims. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.
